The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in the history of science. In this paper we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The approach is based on the notion of a category of functions, which is a generalisation of the notion of a function between sets. The category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is shown to be equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between the appropriate categories of functions. This provides a mathematical foundation for the theory of quantum measurement. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle. (Read more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize production and yields, and the impact of climate change on the stability of maize production and yields, in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in the major maize-producing countries. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the major maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in consumption of individual plant species. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size, digestive physiology, and location, all species consumed a range of plant species, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need to consider the full range of species in studies of niche partitioning and coexistence, and to consider the potential for species to coexist even when they are highly similar in resource use. This is particularly important in light of the current global trend toward the loss of biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely across businesses, and many businesses expect to remain open for the long term. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean. We also show that the global load of floating plastic debris is much less than the load of other pollutants, such as oil, in the ocean. This is a first step toward understanding the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the most important biological function for all animals. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most limiting factor in the evolution of animals. We show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the metabolic power of the mother, and that this is the case across a wide range of animals, from insects to humans.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA and to improve the quality of life of patients. This article is protected by copyright. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also the primary regulator of the contractility of the blood vessels, the hemostasis of the blood, and the immune response to infection. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources, and to coordinate its responses. Here, the nature of the communication system between endothelial cells has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This is important for the health of the body.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, both for public health and for researchers. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are two functionally and structurally coupled domains in K+ channels. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the allosteric communication between these two domains. We have shown that this residue is essential for the C-type inactivation gating and for the allosteric coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic ecosystem that is influenced by the host, the diet, and the microbial community itself. The role of the microbiome in the health of the host is well established, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tracts of herbivores. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are active producers of natural products that could be used as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a challenging task. The use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures that can be digitally synthesized into composite materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit highly nonlinear responses. The structures are also heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design mechanical devices with desired behaviors. It is expected to inspire the design of other complex systems in nature and artificial.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of the red blood cell. The hemoglobin expression pattern in the human body is highly regulated and is a function of the developmental stage of the cell. This study demonstrates that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 miRNA pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and can reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This study provides evidence that the hemoglobin expression pattern in humans is regulated by a developmental mechanism.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. We found that mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, highly frequent in cancer, confers resistance to ferroptosis, and that this resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), which in turn regulates the lipogenic enzyme stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). These findings have important implications for the development of new therapies for cancer, as well as other diseases in which ferroptosis resistance is a major obstacle to treatment. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling through STIM proteins, which are up-regulated in hypertension. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Instead, the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational approaches to design new antibiotics. It is expected to be a valuable tool for the scientific community to address the challenge of antibiotic resistance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness and performance of the reader. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB is consistent with the Os originating from the Earth. In contrast, the Os in the YDB site in Pennsylvania is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is still debated. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by other factors. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its function is not limited to the control of self-reactive T cells.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this success remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive view of the evolution of beetles, including the origins of their major feeding habits, such as leaf mining and wood boring. Our results suggest that the evolution of herbivory in beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be applicable to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation, and suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of the human species.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE is a major component of the senescent synapse, which is a major target of the complement system in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in the regulation of the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 is associated with increased levels of C1q, a major component of senescent synapses, in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key part of the core–mantle boundary transition zone, which is the boundary between the core and mantle. The inner core is a solid because it is cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the nucleation of other parts of the core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors. These findings also highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is the only known site of evolution of the language faculty. Despite its importance, the brain’s processing of language is one of the most difficult problems in neuroscience. Here, we show that artificial neural networks, a type of machine learning model, can predict a large fraction of the brain’s activity during language processing. Our results provide computational evidence that the brain’s processing of language is predictive in nature. This is a major advance in our understanding of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to the success of the algorithms or the success of the models. We show that the success of DL is due to the success of the models. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. These results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the health care system, and the failure of people to follow the rules. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published 45 years ago. It is often claimed that the study’s design flaws led to the conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that this is not the case, and that the study’s methodology was flawed from the start. We discuss the implications of this unique case study for the study of human behavior and the interpretation of past and future research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for the development of two distinct clinical syndromes, namely, lepromatous and lepromatous-like leprosy. The genomes of these two bacteria are very similar, and we show that the events that led to the loss of genes in M. lepromatosis occurred before the divergence of the two species. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the common ancestor of the two species than is M. leprae. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of leprosy and the development of new leprosy vaccines. (Less)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a central question in the field of quantum information and statistical physics. In this work, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our results against the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. Our results are expected to be applicable to a wide class of systems, and to provide a starting point for the study of the dynamics of entropy in isolated quantum systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to stop the pandemic. In this study, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that was recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine candidate was shown to be highly attenuated in vitro and in vivo, and it is protective in a relevant hamster model. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This study provides a promising vaccine candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, there is no evidence that rats were present in Europe during this period. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the main transmission pathway for plague during the Second Pandemic. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats, and they have important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe. The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain size is not always a good proxy for the evolution of brain power. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is better understood by analyzing the number of neurons rather than by brain size. This is important because the number of neurons is the basic unit of computation in the brain. The study also shows that the evolution of brain power is not a simple story of brain size increasing or decreasing. Instead, it is a story of brain size increasing and decreasing, but with major increases in the number of neurons. This is important because it shows that the evolution of brain power is not only about increasing brain size but also about increasing the number of neurons.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data also suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for the treatment of cancer. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not well understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is enhanced by a mechanical torque that it generates upon binding to the filament. This mechanism is critical to the function of ADF in cells, where filaments are highly interconnected and under mechanical stress. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of mechanical stress in the action of ADF in cells. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of mechanical stress in the action of ADF in other contexts, such as in vitro.

Fructose, a common sweetener in soft drinks, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of these two sugars have been unclear. Here, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and for the design of food products that promote healthy eating habits. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we show that the settlement history of Madagascar is more complex than previously thought. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of different ancestries, and that the settlement history of Madagascar is not only the result of a single event. In addition, we show that the genomic diversity is influenced by geography, and that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the conservation of the biodiversity and the cultural diversity of Madagascar. It will also be useful for the understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives, and for the design of social media platforms. It also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is the central protein-synthesizing machine in the cell, and the mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are modified in many ways. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings have implications for the structure and function of the ribosome and the translation machinery. They also suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have a modest impact on translation. This study provides insight into the role of Ψ in mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater use of time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging and well-being.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important and least understood aspects of mammalian evolution. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the host antiviral defense response.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the type IV pili of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the surface. This leads to the activation of a chemosensory system that regulates the production of the virulence factor pyocyanin and the ability to cause disease.

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global problem, and the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity is well established. However, the extent of pesticide contamination is poorly known, and the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity is poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination to surface water and the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread, and that the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity is substantial. These results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination to surface water and the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the lymph nodes of free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the spread of COVID-19. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the problems and proposes solutions. The problems are the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to people’s livelihoods and food systems. The paper proposes that the costs of climate change should be included in the analysis of whether to build a dam and that the benefits of a dam should be more accurately assessed. It also proposes that the industry should be required to pay for the costs of climate change and that the industry should be required to pay for the costs of displacement and compensation.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of intense research for the past 30 y. However, the mechanisms underlying the disease are still poorly understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary toxic species in AD, and that it is the Aβ-burdened neuron that is the primary source of the inflammatory response.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens is still missing. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant already in the fourth century B.C.E. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. This suggests that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. We have found that the folding of maltose binding protein is more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress conditions has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. We also show that, in the absence of ApaH, the activity of a second decapping enzyme, RppH, is increased, and that this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress conditions. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in reducing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the connection of our model to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models. We also discuss the implications of our model for the study of the sandpile model and for the development of a tropical toy model.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be further improved by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a platform for the study of the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of materials. Our findings will help to advance the development of diamond-based devices and materials.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungi is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and mode of action of a plant immune peptide, NCR044, against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular interactions between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular interactions between the sexes during the life history of sperm.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF is a mechanosensitive protein that can be switched between two states by changes in flow. The A1 domain is also a switch for the binding of VWF to the platelet receptor, glycoprotein Ibα. The A1 domain is a promising target for the treatment of VWD.

The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately connected to human health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on the human body, is poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive view of the human virome, and the results are used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. This work will help to guide future research and to better understand the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes, which provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. Ion channels are also involved in a variety of diseases, such as epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and hypertension. The pore gates of ion channels are the main sites of ion flow regulation. We studied the relationship between the activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery of the K+ channel BK. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion flow and the development of new drugs for diseases involving ion channels. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of infection. Here, we show that the parasite uses a number of physical mechanisms to alter the red blood cell surface, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work opens up a number of new questions, including the identity of the host cell receptors and the role of the host cell cytoskeleton in the invasion process. (Read more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be improved by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that the bandgap can be opened reversibly by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. While the importance of humidity in the transmission of influenza virus has been well established, the impact of low humidity on host defense and disease outcome is not well understood. Here, we show that mice housed in low relative humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza virus infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence in the left hemisphere, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly decreases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, and it is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of sentence processing may be useful for understanding the brain’s processing of other types of well-formed sequences, such as protein sequences and DNA strands.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of the embryo. Axin is a protein that is involved in the degradation of β-catenin, which is a protein that is involved in the regulation of the expression of many genes. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and that this differential regulation is important for the proper functioning of the Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding and energy homeostasis. Here we describe a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the ventral tegmental area and to the substantia nigra, and that inhibit LH neurons, induces vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is necessary for this effect. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we have identified a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of the sustainable management of nitrogen in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to develop a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts to communities and training and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can hear in all directions, and the web can be easily adjusted to the changing needs of the spider. This provides a unique model to study the outsourcing and supersizing of hearing, and to develop new technologies for sensing and manipulating fluid flows.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to be a major public health concern, with over 280 million cases and 5.4 million deaths worldwide. The availability of vaccines is a major factor in controlling the pandemic. Recombinant subunit vaccines are well-established and proven interventions, but their production costs are high. Here we report a strategy to reduce the cost of subunit vaccines for COVID-19, by engineering the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the virus spike protein to improve its yield, affinity, and immunogenicity. This strategy can be applied to other vaccines and other viruses. The engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce the severity of disease in hamsters. This work provides a potential solution to the global access problem of COVID-19 vaccines. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of ALK in the development of human cancer has been established by the discovery of mutations in ALK in neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK/LTK are activated by zebrafish and human ALKALs, respectively. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/LTK and ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK/LTK and ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This knowledge will be important for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a major human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in the history of infectious disease. The study of ancient plague genomes has provided a unique window into the origins of this disease, but the number of genomes available has been limited. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period of development. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia, rapid dispersal across continents, and a stepwise pattern of gene loss. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its adaptation to the flea vector. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (PsycINFO Database Record

The fate of carbon (C) in the soil is a key determinant of the global carbon cycle and climate. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has released massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reducing this C loss remains highly uncertain. We show that the management of pastures with rotational grazing and the integration of legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can sequester more C in the soil than conventional annual cropping systems on Mollisols. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of novel viruses emerging from wildlife. We show that the death toll and economic loss from SARS-CoV-2 are a consequence of the spillover of a novel virus from an animal reservoir. We also show that the risk of spillover of novel viruses is higher than that of known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of the nectar is one of the main cues that animals use to locate the plant. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and show that the same enzymes are involved in the production of other pigments in the same plant. This work provides evidence for the existence of a convergent evolution of the red nectar trait in two different species, both of which are visited by vertebrates. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of the evolution of the color of the nectar.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of major demographic changes, which have shaped the genetic structure of the population today. However, the processes that occurred during the period between the migrations of the Germanic peoples and the arrival of the Vikings are largely unknown. Here we present the genome of a woman from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who had a skull deformation that was probably caused by a blow to the head. Our analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of the other individuals indicates that she was part of a group of women who had a very different origin compared to the rest of the population. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This indicates that the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe in the past are still ongoing today.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells.
