The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible, cost-effective, and resource-efficient approach to identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate that mNGS can identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. We also show that mNGS can identify pathogens that are not included in the clinical workflow, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, which is a zoonotic pathogen that can cause severe disease in humans. These findings have implications for the early detection of emerging pathogens, and for the development of mNGS-based surveillance systems in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the pathogen landscape in other settings, and to develop mNGS-based surveillance systems.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the replicative pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart, which is important for the replication of the lagging strand template. Our results also indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more processive than its S. cerevisiae counterpart, which is important for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. Finally, our results suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is less stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart, which is important for the repair of DNA lesions. These results have implications for the replication of the lagging strand template and the repair of DNA lesions in humans. They also provide a foundation for the development of more efficient and safer DNA polymerases for therapeutic applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the successful evolution of such a ribozyme.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 years. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is important for urban planning, urban economics, and urban sociology.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is mainly supportive. The current study shows that tocilizumab, which is effective in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, may be effective in the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to control copper availability is therefore important for their survival. The role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis has been unknown, but here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the existence of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is more widespread than previously appreciated. This work provides a model for the evolution of metal homeostasis in fungi and opens up new avenues for the discovery of antifungal natural products. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of silica, is a rare event in nature. It is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure melts. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment, and the origin of the amorphous silica, are consistent with the formation of the sediment in a hot, dry climate. The detection of post-lithification fracture/vein fill of anhydrite in a sedimentary mudstone is also significant.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of colitis by inducing the expression of the Th1 cytokine IFN-γ, whereas another subset of Th17 cells can support the development of Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results have important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to the development of inflammatory bowel disease. They also have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to the development of other autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is also driven by nonmotor neuron cells, such as astrocytes. However, the mechanisms of disease are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-associated cells from living patients, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of its vector, the blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We identify a protein in the vector that binds to the bacterial cell wall, which alters the permeability of the gut and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, and which is essential for the pathogen to colonize the vector. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors, and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is important for the animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for their survival. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates, and that it is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG is methylated at an m6A residue in the 3′-UTR, which is demethylated by ALKBH5. ALKBH5 expression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cell-like, and is associated with the maintenance of the cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 is a mediator of the maintenance of the cancer stem cell phenotype in breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. We report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles to the present day. (Less)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the evidence points to a combination of factors. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age model provides a basis for evaluating the relative roles of rate-dependent and state-dependent processes in the extinction and recovery, and for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in a variety of biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) in mice and find that RORα is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This study provides insights into the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of all chemistry. They are the key to understanding the behavior of matter and the universe. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a major step forward in the understanding of the behavior of matter under pressure.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has the potential to offset some of the warming caused by human activities. However, the risk of more extreme fires under climate change means that the full potential of fire to mitigate climate change is not yet realized. Our study highlights the importance of human activities in shaping the future of fire regimes and the need to consider both climate and human drivers of fire in future projections.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont in a light-producing organ of a squid. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the organ is colonized by the symbionts. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the environment, and may also have implications for the health of the host. (Less)

Text data are ubiquitous, but the latent patterns in these data are difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent patterns in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. Our method can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which it established itself in rodents. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks. We find that the introduction of plague into European harbors was preceded by climate fluctuations that lasted for 15 y, and that these climate fluctuations were associated with the presence of plague reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the introduction of plague into Europe was the consequence of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium, rather than a single introduction. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the history of the second plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important in the recycling of nutrients. They are also a source of food for a number of species, including sea stars, sea otters, and sea otters. The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) outbreak has had a significant impact on the ecosystem, and the identification of the agent responsible for the disease is of great importance for understanding the disease and its impact.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we show that the settlement history of Madagascar is more complex than previously thought. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of different ancestries, and that the settlement history of Madagascar was not homogeneous. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the conservation of the biodiversity of the island. It will also be useful for the study of the human population dynamics and the origin of the human diversity. Finally, it will be useful for the study of the human population dynamics and the origin of the human diversity.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We also show that the RNA also encodes a protein that interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress genes. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a mechanism that has evolved to control the expression of genes. This work provides insight into the evolution of the dual-function RNA. It also provides a model for how the protein encoded by the RNA may function. This model may be useful in the future development of antibiotics that target the protein encoded by the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data, and propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the management of agricultural production, and for the development of new systems for the collection of crop information.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not dependent on the firing of neurons, and it is not limited to the storage of a small amount of information. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key example of the interplay between selection and mutation. We show that the evolutionary rate of the plastid genome is a function of the level of functional reduction, the lifestyle of the host, and the level of parasitism. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. This finding is important for the public and policy makers, as it highlights the sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the probability of such an event will increase by a factor of 10 to 100 by the year 2100 under the two most likely scenarios of future emissions. This highlights the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to reduce the risk of such extreme events in SSA. This study also highlights the importance of using high-resolution models to understand the causes of extreme events. This approach is essential to understand the causes of extreme events and to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to them. This is particularly important in SSA, where the risk of extreme droughts is increasing.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” has been a major event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, in red trinitite, is a major event in the history of science and technology.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of energy on Earth. The biosynthesis of the light-harvesting pigments, (bacterio)chlorophylls, is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the synthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in autoimmune diseases remain largely unknown. In this study, we identified a key role of neuroinflammation in the later stage of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) and found that ASK1 signaling in microglia plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1 signaling in microglia is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in EAE. Our study also provides a rationale for the use of ASK1 inhibitors in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases and autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased, and that this increase is also due to human activities. These findings have important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the etiology is not fully understood. In this study, we identified a common mechanism of autism-risk genes, which is the inability to forget. This mechanism is conserved in flies and mammals, and it is likely to be involved in the etiology of autism.

This work is the first to report cross-national evidence of negativity biases in the reaction of people around the world to news content. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of individual-level variation in the extent to which people are affected by negative news content. The results suggest that, on average, people are more affected by negative news content than positive news content, and that this is true across a wide range of countries and cultures. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry channel, the CRAC channel, is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, associated with a Stormorken syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy, and in ORAI1, associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis and tubular myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain is dependent on the presence of a defined population of neurons, the spreading neurons, and that this spreading is dependent on the endocytic machinery. We also show that the release of aggregates from spreading neurons requires the activity of the endocytic machinery. These findings provide a model for the spreading of aggregates in the brain and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets for neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bats are increasingly recognized as reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses, but the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein, Myotis pilosus (MTX), that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), an enzyme that is essential for the generation of the potent lipid chemoattractant leukotriene B4 (LTB4). MTX potently inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of LTA4H in the generation of the potent lipid chemoattractant LTB4 and its role in the immune response. This study may also have implications for the development of new antiviral drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this process, and is up-regulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they block cancer growth in vivo. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is reversed in cancer cells. Finally, we show that cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT activity for glycine import, and that this is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings have implications for cancer treatment, and for the development of new inhibitors of SHMT. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a hallmark of the disease. However, the proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions contain a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a period of great change in the history of life. One of the most important changes was the origin of the flowering plants. The origin of the flowering plants is often considered to have occurred in a darkened forest habitat. However, the origin of the flowering plants in a darkened forest is not supported by the fossil record. Instead, the origin of the flowering plants in a darkened forest is based upon a few isolated fossils. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous flowering plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to both virologists and evolutionary biologists. Here we present the genomes of five ancient parvoviruses, which are the smallest known viruses, from individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is ∼12.6 thousand years old, and that the most recent common ancestor of the two most common parvovirus genotypes is ∼12.6 thousand years old. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that the evolution of parvoviruses is slower than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global change. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the effects of climate change. We also show that the rate of acceleration is increasing, which is consistent with the predictions of climate models.

Pain is a common experience, but the experience of pain is changing. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing with age in America today, but that the increase is less than the increase in age alone. We also show that the increase in pain is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in providing a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the location of the leaving group, the protonation states of the active site residues, and the orientation of the water molecules. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding the mechanism of the enzyme. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the available treatment options are limited. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may help to reduce the time needed to develop effective treatments for these diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the mutualistic symbiosis between animals and their microorganisms. They also suggest that the provision of nutrients to microorganisms may be a more general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of epithelial cells in the body of animals.

This paper describes a series of experiments and field trials that tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can be sustained. This work has implications for the future of education, as well as for the future of the criminal justice system.

DNA alkylation is one of the major sources of DNA damage in the cell. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is recognized by pol II with high fidelity, whereas the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion is recognized with high mutational fidelity. In addition, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. They also provide a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of DNA alkylation-induced diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. In this study, we determined the role of the spike protein in the infection of human lung-derived cells. We found that the sequential cleavage of the spike protein is required for efficient infection of human lung cells, and that the cleavage of the spike protein is necessary for the infection of cells relevant to lung infection. These findings suggest that the sequential cleavage of the spike protein is a determinant of the infection of human lung cells, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 61.8% and decreased the proportion of meat meals purchased by 14.5%. These results have important implications for the food system and for the health of the population. They suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets in high-income countries could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. This approach could be used to help achieve the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find that each oncogene has a different glycoproteome, and that the glycoproteome is also altered by the oncogenes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the surfaceome and glycoproteome in cancer cells, and for the discovery of new cancer targets and biomarkers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have been the subject of much debate. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share in 1996 to 2018 in three states that implemented universal vote-by-mail in a staggered fashion. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and/or immune suppression. This work provides a molecular understanding of the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease, and may lead to the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. It is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in the face of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for thinking about the strength of associations in the face of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The discovery of the ligands for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the biology of RTKs. In this study, we show that the ligands play an important role in the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. We also show that the ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, the pigment cells of the skin and the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a model for the study of the physiological role of the ligands and their ligands in the development of the skin and the eye. It also provides a model for the study of the role of ligands in the development of iridophores.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem, and the molecular mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still poorly understood. Herein, we report a role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis. We also provide evidence that STING is required for β-cell function and that its nuclear localization is essential for the regulation of β-cell function. These findings have important implications for the understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D and for the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

Influenza A viruses are the cause of annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the virions, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected. However, the molecular details of this mechanism remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to identify the mechanisms that regulate the development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, in the treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the role of people in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Our findings highlight the need to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 years. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is important for urban planning, urban economics, and urban sociology.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying processes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may help to explain the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in the face of environmental change. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn triggers the tumorigenic process. We also show that the activity level of the JNK pathway is critical to maintain the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be exploited to control the activity of the JNK pathway and to prevent the development of intestinal tumors. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. This work may also have implications for the control of the activity of the JNK pathway in other tissues.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive, the majority of patients do not respond to endocrine therapy. In addition, the majority of breast cancers are resistant to the chemotherapy drug paclitaxel. We show that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy leads to the up-regulation of the orphan receptor ROR1, which in turn enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still a matter of debate. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of overfishing and other threats. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management decisions to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide lead to a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water, and a full cell presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be essential for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. We also identify a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type, which is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite or mutations disrupting sensory activity. These findings provide a framework for understanding the molecular control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

The process of recombination is essential for the proper functioning of the genome, but the details of its spatial organization are not well understood. We use a population of wild-type and mutant plants to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that the spatial pattern of recombination is conserved across species, and that it is likely to be ancient, as it is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a small fraction of neurons is sufficient to generate the observed signal fluctuations. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a small number of networks, which are assumed to be the main functional modules of the brain. However, the existence of these networks is not supported by direct measurements of the activity of the neurons that generate the observed fluctuations. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the brain can be used to identify the main functional modules of the brain, and that this activity is altered in disease. This approach provides a direct measure of the organization of the brain, which can be used to study the function of the brain and to monitor the progression of disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for proper translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is found on pre-mRNAs and mature mRNAs. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persist in blood monocytes during the long-term follow-up of the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes.
