Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target in the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in plants and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Read more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We also show that the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning are exacerbated by global warming. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species in the design of future experiments and in the interpretation of experimental results.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, which is involved in spatial navigation. The organization of the MEC is important for understanding the formation of the spatial map in the hippocampus. However, the anatomical and functional organization of the MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the spatial organization of neurons in the MEC and parasubiculum during free-moving behavior. Our results suggest that the organization of the MEC is more complex than previously thought. Specifically, we found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings have implications for our understanding of the formation of the spatial map in the brain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host plant, but not for the flowering of the dodder. This study illustrates the importance of FTs in interplant communication and the role of flowering in the synchronization of flowering of host and parasite.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatal pathway form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of their parent cell bodies in the substantia nigra. These clusters of cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Within the bouquets, striosomal fibers are found to be tightly intertwined with the dopamine-containing dendrites and also with other types of neurons and fibers. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to the people around us. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and then rated the felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the electrical signal that causes the heart to beat. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of the heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure and other factors. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are located in the wall of the right atrium. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the electrical signal that causes the heart to beat. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of the heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure and other factors.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in defense against herbivores has been debated. Here, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants increases resistance to the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in defense against herbivores, and that this interaction may be a general phenomenon in plants. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for pest management. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the macrophage lipidome. Our results provide a link between tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid metabolism and reveal a role of alkylglycerol monooxygenase in the regulation of the macrophage lipidome.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this is not the case for the Great Lakes, which are fed by 23,000 rivers and streams. We show that the nutrient loads from small tributaries are a significant fraction of the total, and that they are biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that the nearshore areas of these lakes are more vulnerable to eutrophication from small tributaries than previously thought. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication, and the need to better understand the role that these sources play in the health of large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We show that the dynamics of the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. We also show that the dynamics of the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We also show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that these changes can be used to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other types of brain dysfunction on the EEG. This framework may also be useful for the development of new treatments for patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of the Earth’s climate is not well understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was associated with an increase in the amount of organic matter entering the ocean and an increase in the amount of anoxia on the seafloor. These results have implications for our understanding of the history of the Earth’s climate and for the potential for abrupt climate change in the future.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil, a major driver of tropical deforestation. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in the context of a rapidly expanding global palm oil industry. Our findings also highlight the need for more rigorous evaluation of the effectiveness of certification schemes in reducing tropical deforestation. This is particularly important in light of the recent announcement by the RSPO that it will no longer certify new palm oil plantations. Our findings suggest that certification may be more effective in reducing deforestation in the existing portfolio of plantations than in preventing new deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in some species, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of the organism. Here we show that the evolution of multiple alleles in the sex determination pathway can produce a modular system of sexual traits, where the same genotype can produce different phenotypes. This modularity is likely to have important implications for the evolution of sexual dimorphism and the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and damage to photoreceptor cells. In this study, we show that the level of intracellular iron can influence the fate of the bisretinoid A2E, a molecule that is known to be photooxidized and degraded in the retina. We also show that the level of iron in the retina can be influenced by the level of iron in the blood. These findings have implications for the health of the retina and may lead to the development of strategies to protect the retina from damage. (Read more)

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the mechanisms behind the evolution of specialization are not well understood. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in the pelagic cnidarian siphonophores is linked to the evolution of the tentilla, the side branches armed with nematocysts. We show that the evolution of the tentilla is linked to the evolution of the prey type, and that the evolution of the tentilla is linked to the evolution of the prey type. These findings help us understand the evolution of specialization, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and least understood aspects of human evolution. This is because the fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse and because the features of the hominin hand that are shared with modern humans and Neandertals are not present in early hominins. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from 1.42 Mya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this process, and is up-regulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they block cancer growth in vivo. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is reversed in cancer cells. Finally, we show that cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT activity for glycine import, and that this is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the design of more effective small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study provides evidence that deforestation is having a negative impact on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This is particularly important given that the global population is expected to increase by 2.5 billion by 2050, and that the majority of this growth will occur in rural areas.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the success of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
